communication: Communication skill: Use an “I feel ___ when ___ because ___” statement once today.
Communication skill: Before replying, paraphrase what you heard in one sentence.
Communication skill: Ask: “Do you want solutions or just listening?”
Communication skill: Use a softer start-up: begin with appreciation, then the request.
Communication skill: Replace one criticism with a clear request.
Communication skill: Take a 60-second pause before responding in a tense moment.
Communication skill: Name the shared goal: “I’m on your team; I want us to ____.”
Communication skill: Validate first: “That makes sense.” Then ask one question.
Communication skill: Assume positive intent and ask for clarity.
Communication skill: End a hard talk with one thing you love about them.
Repair move: If you feel defensive, say: “I’m getting defensive; I want to understand.”
Repair move: If you interrupt, say: “Sorry—finish your thought.”
Repair move: If voices rise, suggest: “Can we take 10 minutes and come back?”
Repair move: Offer a repair attempt: “Can we reset?”
Repair move: Apologize for your tone if it slips.
Repair move: Thank them for sharing even if it’s hard to hear.
Repair move: Ask: “What part felt most important to you?”
Repair move: Use gentle curiosity: “Help me see it your way.”
Repair move: Ask: “What would make this feel fair?”
Repair move: Confirm next step: “What do we agree to try?”
Check-in: Have a 5-minute daily check-in: one good thing + one need.
Check-in: Have a 10-minute weekly preview: schedules, stressors, needs.
Check-in: Ask: “What’s one thing I did this week that helped?”
Check-in: Ask: “What’s one thing we can improve this week?”
Check-in: Ask: “Anything you’ve been holding in that I should know?”
Check-in: Share: “One thing I’m proud of you for is …”
Check-in: Share: “One worry I have is … and what I need is …”
Check-in: Ask: “What would support you most tomorrow?”
Check-in: Ask: “How connected do you feel (1–10) and why?”
Check-in: Ask: “What would move us one point higher?”
Boundary: If you need time, say: “I need a break; I’ll come back at ___.”
Boundary: Say one boundary kindly today: “I can do ___, but not ___.”
Boundary: Ask for what you need clearly, without hinting.
Boundary: Choose one topic to table and schedule a time to revisit.
Boundary: Ask permission before sensitive feedback: “Can I share something?”
Today, start a conversation by saying “I want to understand you—can you tell me more?”
Today, start a conversation by saying “What’s the most important part of this for you?”
Today, start a conversation by saying “What are you hoping I’ll do?”
Today, start a conversation by saying “What would make you feel supported right now?”
Today, start a conversation by saying “What does ‘better’ look like to you?”
